prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BugNebula - CO, Recombination lines, SiO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal is dedicated to observe simultaneously the CO(2-1) line, the recombination line H(30)alpha, and the SiO v=0 (5-4) line. As bonus lines, the rarer isotopologue 29SiO (v=0, 5-4), the SiO v=1,2 (5-4), SiC2 (10-9) and the C(30)alpha lines are included in this frequency range.
The recombination lines will allow to map the spatial distribution and the physical parmaters of the ionized gas, while the CO(2-1) line will be used to probe the spatial extent and gas mass of the individual clumps. The SiO lines (included in the different basebands are the SiO v=0,1,2 (5-4) lines will be used as a tracer of O-rich chemistry, to be compared with the C-rich chemical tracers that will be obtained in Science Goal 2.
The Bug nebula is a O-rich, intermediate-mass progenitor PN. The comparison with the Ring Nebula will allow to differentiate the role of the progenitor mass in the chemical evolution of the PN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The typical line width of the individual clumps is not known precisely, but will likely be of few km/s.
The kinematical analysis will be based on the comparison of the centroid velocity of the individual clumps, which span a much broader interval (~30 km/s).
The typical spatial extent of the individual clumps that are the object of the study of this project are ~3-4". The chosen configuration will allow to resolve the individual clumps.

Based on the HST images, the typical clump size is ~ 3-4", thus the emission of the individual clumps will fill the proposed syntethised beam of 1". Our line intensity estimates for the individual clumps are calculated using our LVG code MADEX assuming a gas density of 10^5cm-3, Tk = 40K and an expansion velocity of 3 km/s (corresponding to lines of ~6km/s at half power). We assumed also a CO abundance relative to H2 of [CO]=10^-4. For SiO, we repeated the calculations using typical abundance for the O-rich and C-rich cases ([SiO] = 10^-4 and [SiO] = 10^-7, respectively).
The CO(2-1) line intensity calculated by our model are ~30K, which will allow to observe the clumps with a very high S/N. This will allow to distinguish the individual clumps.
Our model predicts that in the O-rich case the SiO (v=0, 5-4) line will be as bright as the CO line (~30K) whereas in the C-rich case, the line intensity will be ~5K. Thus, the demanded sensitivity of 160mK will allow to map this line in both cases with a S/N>30.
The 29SiO, SiC2 and the C(30)alpha lines may be detected with a lower S/N, and will provide additional constraints on the chemistry and physical parameters.
The continuum sensitivity (0.12 mJy) is sufficient to meaure the expected dust continuum emission from individual clumps (1-10 mJy).

The demanded data rate (12.2MB/s) is only slightly above the policy value. However, this configuration allows to cover several bonus lines that could be detected with the proposed S/N.
We selected a spectral averaging of 2 to reduce the data rate.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BugNebula - CCH, c-C3H2, HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This setup will allow to observe several lines of key molecules involved in carbon-based chemistry.
CCH and c-C3H2 are typical tracers of carbon chemistry in photon-dominated region, whereas HCN and HC3N will give further constraints in the physical conditions of the clumps, and on the chemical pathways to the formation of larger molecules.
This spectral setup also incldues C3H+ (11-10) which is a typical tracer of photon-induced chemistry) and several other (fainter) lines of c-C3H2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The typical line width of the individual clumps is not known precisely, but will likely be of few km/s.
The kinematical analysis will be based on the comparison of the centroid velocity of the individual clumps, which span a much broader interval (~30 km/s).
The typical spatial extent of the individual clumps that are the object of the study of this project are ~3-4". The chosen configuration will allow to resolve the individual clumps.

Based on the HST images, the typical clump size is ~ 3-4", thus the emission of the individual clumps will fill the proposed syntethised beam of 1". Our line intensity estimates for the individual clumps are calculated using our LVG code MADEX assuming a gas density of 10^5cm-3, Tk = 40K and an expansion velocity of 3 km/s (corresponding to lines of ~6km/s at half power). We assumed also CCH, c-C3H2 and HCN abundances relative to H2 of [CCH]=10^-8 and [c-C3H2] = 10^-8.
Based on our model prediction, the HCN line will be very bright (~20K) and will be mapped with a very high S/N ratio (>100). The intensity of the CCH and c-C3H2 lines will be I(CCH)~2K and I(c-C3H2)~3K. The demanded sensitivity of 0.160K will allow to obtain a S/N~ 12 for the faintest lines included in this setup.
The continuum sensitivity (0.12 mJy) is sufficient to meaure the expected dust continuum emission from individual clumps (1-10 mJy).

The demanded data rate (12.2MB/s) is only slightly above the policy value. However, this configuration allows to cover several bonus lines that could be detected with the proposed S/N (C3H+, c-C3H2).
We selected a spectral averaging of 2 to reduce the data rate.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RingNebula - CO, Recombination lines, SIO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal is dedicated to observe simultaneously the CO 2-1 line, the recombination line H(30)alpha, and the SiO v=0 (5-4) line. As bonus lines, the rarer isotopologue 29SiO (v=0, 5-4), the SiO v=1,2 (5-4), SiC2 (10-9) and the C(30)alpha lines are included in this frequency range.
The recombination lines will allow to map the spatial distribution and the physical parmaters of the ionized gas, while the CO(2-1) line will be used to probe the spatial extent and gas mass of the individual clumps. The SiO lines (included in the different basebands are the SiO v=0,1,2 (5-4) lines will be used as a tracer of O-rich chemistry, to be compared with the C-rich chemical tracers that will be obtained in Science Goal 4.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The typical line width of the individual clumps is not known precisely, but will likely be of few km/s.
The kinematical analysis will be based on the comparison of the centroid velocity of the individual clumps, which span a much broader interval (~30 km/s).
We selected a lower spectral resolution selected for the H recombination line (spectral averaging = 4) as these lines is expected to be broader (tens of km/s).
The typical spatial extent of the individual clumps that are the object of the study of this project are ~3-4". The chosen configuration will allow to resolve the individual clumps.

Based on the HST images, the typical clump size is ~ 3-4", thus the emission of the individual clumps will fill the proposed syntethised beam of 1". Our line intensity estimates for the individual clumps are calculated using our LVG code MADEX assuming a gas density of 10^5cm-3, Tk = 40K and an expansion velocity of 3 km/s (corresponding to lines of ~6km/s at half power).. We assumed also a CO abundance relative to H2 of [CO]=10^-4. For SiO, we repeated the calculations using typical abundance for the O-rich and C-rich cases ([SiO] = 10^-4 and [SiO] = 10^-7, respectively).
The CO(2-1) line intensity calculated by our model are ~30K, which will allow to observe the clumps with a very high S/N. This will allow to distinguish the individual clumps.
Our model predicts that in the O-rich case the SiO (v=0, 5-4) line will be as bright as the CO line (~30K) whereas in the C-rich case, the line intensity will be ~2K. Thus, the demanded sensitivity of 160mK will allow to map this line in both cases with a S/N>13.
The 29SiO, SiC2 and the C(30)alpha lines may be detected with a lower S/N, and will provide additional constraints on the chemistry and physical parameters.
The continuum sensitivity (0.12 mJy) is sufficient to meaure the expected dust continuum emission from individual clumps (1-10 mJy).

The demanded data rate (12.2MB/s) is only slightly above the policy value. However, this configuration allows to cover several bonus lines that could be detected with the proposed S/N.
We selected a spectral averaging of 2 to reduce the data rate.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RingNebula - CCH, c-C3H2, HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This setup will allow to observe several lines of key molecules involved in carbon-based chemistry.
CCH and c-C3H2 are typical tracers of carbon chemistry in photon-dominated region, whereas HCN and HC3N will give further constraints in the physical conditions of the clumps, and on the chemical pathways to the formation of larger molecules.
This spectral setup also incldues one C3H+ (11-10, which is a typical tracer of photon-induced chemistry) and several other (fainter) lines of c-C3H2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The typical line width of the individual clumps is not known precisely, but will likely be of few km/s.
The kinematical analysis will be based on the comparison of the centroid velocity of the individual clumps, which span a much broader interval (~30 km/s).
The typical spatial extent of the individual clumps that are the object of the study of this project are ~3-4". The chosen configuration will allow to resolve the individual clumps.

Based on the HST images, the typical clump size is ~ 3-4", thus the emission of the individual clumps will fill the proposed syntethised beam of 1". Our line intensity estimates for the individual clumps are calculated using our LVG code MADEX assuming a gas density of 10^5cm-3, Tk = 40K and an expansion velocity of 3 km/s (corresponding to lines of ~6km/s at half power). We assumed also CCH, c-C3H2 and HCN abundances relative to H2 of [CCH]=10^-8 and [c-C3H2] = 10^-8.
Based on our model prediction, the HCN line will be very bright (~20K) and will be mapped with a very high S/N ratio (>100). The intensity of the CCH and c-C3H2 lines will be I(CCH)~2K and I(c-C3H2)~1.5K. The demanded sensitivity of 0.160K will allow to obtain a S/N~ 9 for the faintest lines included in this setup.
The continuum sensitivity (0.12 mJy) is sufficient to meaure the expected dust continuum emission from individual clumps (1-10 mJy).

The demanded data rate (12.2MB/s) is only slightly above the policy value. However, this configuration allows to cover several bonus lines that could be detected with the proposed S/N (C3H+, c-C3H2).
We selected a spectral averaging of 2 to reduce the data rate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This project seeks to elucidate the role and impact of carbon-chemistry in oxygen-rich planetary nebula (PNe) in relation to the formation of large polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). The objective is to characterize the dense clumps (those seen in stark contrast against the bright (opti- cal) emission from the photo-ionisation region) in two nearby oxygen-rich dual-chemistry planetary nebulae. These compact clumps provide dense shielded environments that retain signatures of the dominant chemistry prevailing at the time the material was ejected in the slow Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) wind, even though presently exposed to the strong UV radiation field of the hot central star. With ALMA we can now efficiently map at high spatial resolution molecular tracers of both oxygen-rich (SiO) and carbon-rich (HCN, CCH, c-C3H2) chemistry in tens to hundreds of clumps throughout the dense inner region and bipolar outflow of two of these nebulae, NGC 6302 and NGC 6720.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institut de Recherche en Astrophysique et Planetologie
